Ian Abraham

I am a PhD candidate in robotics at the Center for Robotics and Biosystems at Northwestern University where I work on optimal sensing and control with Todd D. Murphey.

During my time at Northwestern, interned at the NVIDIA Seattle Robotics Lab. In addition, I was a part of the DARPA FX-3 Urban Swarm Challenge where I was able to implement some of my decentralized swarm work on a swarm of robots. Some of my work was highlighted at ICRA, RSS, and WAFR.

Email  /  GitHub  /  Google Scholar

Research

I am mostly interested in robotics which spans optimal control, active sensing, learning, and swarm control/management. In summary, my work is primarily about enabling robotic systems to be self-sufficient and adaptive.

Active Learning of Dynamics for Data-Driven Control Using Koopman Operators
Ian Abraham, ToddD Murphey
IEEE Transactions on Robotics, 2019

WHISKiT Physics: A three-dimensional mechanical model of the rat vibrissal array
NadinaO Zweifel, NickE Bush, Ian Abraham, ToddD Murphey, MitraJZ Hartmann
bioRxiv, 2019

Active Learning of Dynamics for Data-Driven Control using Koopman Operators
Ian Abraham, Todd D. Murphey
IEEE Transactions on Robotics, 2019
project page / code

This paper presents an active learning strategy for robotic systems that takes into account task information, enables fast learning, and allows control to be readily synthesized by taking advantage of the Koopman operator representation.
Active Area Coverage from Equilibrium
Ian Abraham, Ahalya Prabhakar, ToddD Murphey
Workshop on Algorithmic Foundations of Robotics, 2019

Structured neural network dynamics for model-based control
Alexander Broad, Ian Abraham, Todd Murphey, Brenna Argall
Learning and Inference in Robotics -- Robotics: Science and Systems, 2018

Data-Driven Measurement Models for Active Localization in Sparse Environments
Ian Abraham, Anastasia Mavrommati, ToddD Murphey
Robotics: Science and Systems, 2018

Decentralized ergodic control: distribution-driven sensing and exploration for multiagent systems
Ian Abraham, ToddD Murphey
IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters, 2018

Model-Based Control Using Koopman Operators
Ian Abraham, Gerardo DeLaTorre, ToddD Murphey
Robotics: Science and Systems, 2017

Real-Time Area Coverage and Target Localization using Receding-Horizon Ergodic Exploration
Anastasia Mavrommati, Emmanouil Tzorakoleftherakis, Ian Abraham and Todd D. Murphey
IEEE Transactions on Robotics, 2017
code

Although a number of solutions exist for the problems of coverage, search and target localization—commonly addressed separately—whether there exists a unified strategy that addresses these objectives in a coherent manner without being application-specific remains a largely open research question. In this paper, we develop a receding-horizon ergodic control approach, based on hybrid systems theory, that has the potential to fill this gap.
Real-time area coverage and target localization using receding-horizon ergodic exploration
Anastasia Mavrommati, Emmanouil Tzorakoleftherakis, Ian Abraham, ToddD Murphey
IEEE Transactions on Robotics, 2017

Model-Based Control using Koopman Operators
Ian Abraham Todd D. Murphey
IEEE Transactions on Robotics, 2017
code

Although a number of solutions exist for the problems of coverage, search and target localization—commonly addressed separately—whether there exists a unified strategy that addresses these objectives in a coherent manner without being application-specific remains a largely open research question. In this paper, we develop a receding-horizon ergodic control approach, based on hybrid systems theory, that has the potential to fill this gap.
Ergodic exploration using binary sensing for nonparametric shape estimation
Ian Abraham, Ahalya Prabhakar, MitraJZ Hartmann, ToddD Murphey
IEEE robotics and automation letters, 2017

A nonlinear leg damping model for the prediction of running forces and stability
Ian Abraham, ZhuoHua Shen, Justin Seipel
Journal of Computational and Nonlinear Dynamics, 2015

Ian Abraham, Jingang Yi
